import { describe, it, expect } from 'vitest';
import { Pipeline } from '../../src/pipeline.js';

describe('Pipeline Integration Tests', () => {
  it('should run outline generation successfully', async () => {
    const result = await Pipeline.runPipeline('Test RV Guide', 'daily');
    
    // The pipeline should start successfully and create a run state
    expect(result).toBeDefined();
    expect(result.runState).toBeDefined();
    expect(result.runState.id).toBeDefined();
    expect(result.runState.topic).toBe('Test RV Guide');
    expect(result.runState.bucket).toBe('daily');
    expect(result.runState.currentStage).toBeDefined();
    
    // Should either succeed or fail gracefully with error information
    if (result.success) {
      // If successful, should have progressed through stages
      expect(['outline', 'draft', 'expand', 'polish', 'finalize', 'publish', 'complete']).toContain(result.runState.currentStage);
    } else {
      // If failed, should have error details and stage information
      expect(result.error).toBeDefined();
      expect(result.runState.errors).toBeDefined();
      expect(result.runState.errors.length).toBeGreaterThan(0);
      expect(result.runState.errors[0].stage).toBeDefined();
      expect(result.runState.errors[0].message).toBeDefined();
      expect(result.runState.errors[0].timestamp).toBeDefined();
    }
  }, 120000); // 2 minute timeout for LLM calls

  it('should handle resume functionality', async () => {
    // First run a pipeline that might fail
    const initialResult = await Pipeline.runPipeline('Resume Test Topic', 'daily');
    expect(initialResult.runState.id).toBeDefined();
    
    const runId = initialResult.runState.id;
    
    // Try to resume it
    const resumeResult = await Pipeline.resumePipeline(runId);
    
    expect(resumeResult).toBeDefined();
    expect(resumeResult.runState).toBeDefined();
    expect(resumeResult.runState.id).toBe(runId);
    
    // Should maintain the same topic and bucket
    expect(resumeResult.runState.topic).toBe('Resume Test Topic');
    expect(resumeResult.runState.bucket).toBe('daily');
  }, 120000);

  it('should validate run state persistence', async () => {
    // Run pipeline to create a state
    const result = await Pipeline.runPipeline('Persistence Test', 'weekly');
    const runId = result.runState.id;
    
    // Load the state directly
    const stateResult = await Pipeline.getRunState(runId);
    
    expect(stateResult.success).toBe(true);
    expect(stateResult.data).toBeDefined();
    expect(stateResult.data!.id).toBe(runId);
    expect(stateResult.data!.topic).toBe('Persistence Test');
    expect(stateResult.data!.bucket).toBe('weekly');
  }, 60000);

  it('should list pipeline runs', async () => {
    const listResult = await Pipeline.listRuns();
    
    expect(listResult.success).toBe(true);
    expect(listResult.runs).toBeDefined();
    expect(Array.isArray(listResult.runs)).toBe(true);
    
    // Should have at least some runs from previous tests
    if (listResult.runs!.length > 0) {
      // Each run ID should be a valid UUID format
      const uuidRegex = /^[0-9a-f]{8}-[0-9a-f]{4}-[0-9a-f]{4}-[0-9a-f]{4}-[0-9a-f]{12}$/i;
      listResult.runs!.forEach(runId => {
        expect(runId).toMatch(uuidRegex);
      });
    }
  }, 30000);
});

   398â†’    "content": "# Best Half-Ton Towable Travel Trailers 2025\n\nIntroduction\n\nThis guide helps beginners evaluate lightweight travel trailers that a modern half-ton pickup can tow safely. It covers key weight terms and calculations, vetted 2025 model types, a buyer checklist, towing and maintenance basics, costs and legal considerations, and next steps to schedule test-tows and inspections.\n\n## Quick overview: Can a half-ton truck safely tow a travel trailer?\n\nShort answer: Yesâ€”many half-ton trucks can tow lightweight travel trailers, but safety depends on matching trailer GVWR/UVW and tongue weight to your truckâ€™s published towing and payload ratings; always confirm with your truckâ€™s placard and the trailerâ€™s spec sheet before buying [1][2].\n\nStart by learning the terms: curb weight/dry weight, UVW (unloaded vehicle weight), GVWR (gross vehicle weight rating), and payloadâ€”each limits what you can legally and safely carry or tow [2]. Find your truckâ€™s towing and payload numbers on the door jamb placard, in the ownerâ€™s manual, or on the manufacturer site; use those numbers, not informal estimates, when evaluating trailers [3].\n\nTongue weight (typically 10â€“15% of trailer GVWR for conventional trailers) affects stability and may push payload requirements; heavy tongue weight or visible sway often means adding a weight-distribution hitch and sway control for safe towing [4].\n\nReal towing ranges vary: modern half-tons (F-150, Ram 1500, Silverado 1500) have published towing capacities from roughly 5,000 up to 14,000+ lbs depending on engine, axle, and equipmentâ€”verify your specific model/year before assuming compatibility [1].\n\n### Weight calculations beginners must do\n\nDirect answer: Do this step-by-step checkâ€”truck curb weight + passengers + cargo + trailer tongue weight must be â‰¤ truck payload; trailer UVW + cargo â‰¤ trailer GVWR; use a certified scale or an online towing calculator to confirm numbers [14][13].\n\nWe recommend weighing a fully loaded truck and the specific trailer on certified commercial scales to produce an accurate payload/tongue-weight picture; dealers can often provide a weight ticket for a specific unit [14]. Use online calculators only as an initial screen, then confirm with measured weights before purchase [13].\n\n### Common misconceptions\n\nDirect answer: Manufacturer dry/tare weights are optimistic and leave little margin; a trailerâ€™s GVWR and your hitch class both place hard limits you cannot exceed for safety or legal reasons [2].\n\nDonâ€™t assume a modelâ€™s â€œstartingâ€ weight is what youâ€™ll actually towâ€”options, full water tanks, gear, and aftermarket items add weight fast. Similarly, a hitch or bumperâ€™s class rating can be lower than the truckâ€™s capacity, so check both before hitching up [2].\n\n## Top half-ton towable travel trailers for beginners (2025 picks)\n\nDirect answer: For 2025, look at micro/ultra-lite travel trailers, fiberglass teardrops, compact conventional trailers, and select hybridsâ€”each balances low tow weight with livability; verify UVW/GVWR for the specific trim and options before deciding [5][6].\n\nBelow are practical notes on common beginner-friendly models; ranges are typicalâ€”always check the 2025 spec sheet for the exact unit.\n\n### Forest River R-Pod (Râ€‘Pod) â€” Micro/ultra-light\n\nTypical UVW: ~2,500â€“4,000 lb depending on floorplan and options [5]. The Râ€‘Podâ€™s compact floorplans and optional off-grid packages make it easy to tow and set up quickly, but interior space is limited for families [5]. Best for solo travelers or couples wanting low tow impact and quick campsites.\n\n### Winnebago Micro Minnie / Hike models\n\nExpected UVW/GVWR varies by trim; Micro Minnie/Hike models aim for lightweight construction with good dealer support [6]. Strengths include manufacturer warranty and resale; watch upper-trim floorplans that push toward the top of half-ton limits [6]. Good for buyers who prefer brand support.\n\n### Jayco Jay Feather Micro / Jay Flight SLX\n\nThese models offer family-friendly layouts in lightweight packages; exact tow weights depend on year and options [5]. Pros: versatile floorplans and family features; cons: check specific 2025 trim weights for bunks or options that raise UVW [5]. Ideal for small families needing bunks.\n\n### Casita / Scamp (fiberglass teardrops)\n\nFiberglass shells are durable and often light, making them friendly to older half-ton trucks; UVW is typically low for small floorplans [7]. Pros: longevity and low maintenance; cons: simpler interiors and fewer luxury features [7]. Best for couples wanting low-maintenance rigs.\n\n### Coachmen Clipper Ultra-Lite / KZ Sportsmen Classic\n\nBudget-focused lightweight trailers with multiple floorplans; they deliver value but may use lighter construction materials that affect long-term durability [8]. Pros: affordability and choices; cons: potential trade-offs in long-term ruggedness. Good for first-time buyers on a budget.\n\n### Special mention: Small toy haulers & hybrids under half-ton limits\n\nSome compact toy haulers and hybrid pop-ups can fit within half-ton towing limitsâ€”great for weekend adventurers carrying bikes or kayaksâ€”but check payload carefully for cargo carried in the garage area [5].\n\n### How to verify current 2025 specs\n\nDirect answer: Always request the manufacturer spec sheet and an actual build sheet for the lot unit; ask the dealer for a certified weight ticket when a specific trailer is on-site [13].\n\nManufacturer PDFs list UVW/GVWR for each trim; if buying used, insist on a certified RV inspection and weight verification before purchase [9][13].\n\n## How to choose the right half-ton towable: checklist for beginners\n\nDirect answer: Prioritize confirmed towing capability and payload margin, then match floorplan and systems to your lifestyleâ€”consider construction, axle count, and how tanks/batteries/AC affect weight and range [10].\n\nConstruction choices (aluminum frame vs. laminated) change weight and longevity; single vs. tandem axle influences tracking and load distributionâ€”single axles often weigh less but may limit GVWR [2].\n\nAmenities like large freshwater tanks, multiple batteries, and rooftop AC add weight quickly; plan which systems are essential and which you can add later to stay under payload limits [10].\n\n### Practical checklist before saying â€˜yesâ€™\n\nConfirm truck max payload minus passengers/cargo leaves safe margin for tongue weight; verify brake controller and wiring compatibility; confirm hitch class and consider sway control; and test-drive towing a similar-weight trailer if possible [3][13].\n\n### Floorplan & lifestyle questions to ask\n\nDecide boondocking vs. full-hookup nights, sleeping needs (bunks vs. dedicated bed), and gear storage needs; these choices change not only comfort but also payload requirements and campsite compatibility [11].\n\n## Buying process, costs, and legal/insurance considerations\n\nDirect answer: Inspect frame, axles, brakes, seals, appliances, and electrical on any trailer; budget for insurance, registration, fuel penalty, maintenance, and storageâ€”expect to set aside roughly 1â€“3% of purchase price annually for upkeep [9][10].\n\nFinancing terms depend on lender and trailer age; lightweight new units often qualify for RV loans with typical down payments and terms similar to small RVsâ€”compare lenders and factor total cost of ownership into your decision [10].\n\nCheck state laws on trailer brakes and weight limitsâ€”some states require independent trailer brakes above certain weights or specific endorsements on licenses [11].\n\n### Pre-purchase inspection details\n\nHave a certified RV inspector or experienced dealer check the chassis, frame, axles, brakes, roof seals, slide mechanisms, and electrical system; request a build sheet and any repair history for used units [9].\n\n### Estimating ongoing costs\n\nInclude fuel (towing reduces MPG), tire replacement, brake servicing, roof reseal, and campsite fees. A simple budgeting approach is 1â€“3% of purchase price per year for maintenance plus fuel and site fees based on travel frequency [10].\n\n## Towing, setup, and maintenance basics for beginners\n\nDirect answer: Before towing, confirm hitch and coupler fit, calibrate the brake controller, set mirrors/cameras, and attach safety chains; on the road, maintain safe speeds, manage sway, and use practiced backing techniques; perform routine wheel bearing and seal checks seasonally [11].\n\nUse a weight-distribution hitch and sway control if the trailerâ€™s tongue weight is high or you experience instability; practice backing in an open lot and get comfortable with turn margins and braking distances [4][11].\n\n### Daily pre-trip checklist\n\nCheck tire pressure and condition, verify lights/wiring, secure cargo, ensure hitch coupler is locked and safety chains attached, and confirm tank and propane levels before departure [11].\n\n### Seasonal prep & storage\n\nWinterize plumbing, store batteries in a cool dry place or maintain via tender, protect jacks/tires, and reseal any roof seams before long storage intervals; choose covered storage for longer life when possible [10].\n\n## Lifestyle & travel planning: how a half-ton towable fits your life\n\nDirect answer: Smaller trailers increase campsite options (state parks, private campgrounds, boondocking), reduce fuel and parking constraints, and can work for part-time living with careful space managementâ€”full-time living may require upgrades and compromises [12].\n\nInterpret campsite lengths and pull-through availability to match trailer length; use apps and campground filters to find sites that accept lower-axle-weight rigs and shorter tow vehicles [12].\n\n### Family & social factors\n\nPlan sleeping arrangements and privacy strategies for kids/pets in compact spaces, and build community via RV clubs, owner forums, and local meetups to get hands-on tips from experienced owners [6].\n\n## Next steps & resources\n\nDirect answer: Confirm your truckâ€™s exact payload/towing numbers, choose 2â€“3 models that meet your needs, schedule a test tow and certified inspection, and estimate total purchase plus ownership costs before committing [13].\n\nResources to use next: manufacturer 2025 spec sheets, online towing calculators, certified RV inspectors, and hands-on towing training courses or dealer demo days to build confidence and verify compatibility [13][14].\n",

- Uses `parseInt()` for integer fields like reading_time and word_count
- Uses `parseFloat()` for decimal fields like fleschKincaidScore
- Validates parsed numbers with `!isNaN()` before assigning
- Only converts string values, preserves existing numbers
- Handles case-insensitive boolean strings (`"True"`, `"FALSE"`, etc.)

- âœ… String-to-number conversion for various numeric fields

1. Capturing the real failure (reading_time string validation error)

import { describe, it, expect, beforeAll } from 'vitest';
import { readFile } from 'fs/promises';
import path from 'path';
import { PublisherAgent } from '../../src/agents/PublisherAgent.js';
import type { RunState, Expanded } from '../../src/schemas.js';

describe('PublisherAgent FAQ Section Generation (Real Data TDD)', () => {
  let expandedData: Expanded;

  beforeAll(async () => {
    // Load real run data
    const runPath = path.join(process.cwd(), 'runs/be45aff8-d7ff-4e54-b673-044ffe9a8d99/state.json');
    const runContent = await readFile(runPath, 'utf-8');
    const realRunData: RunState = JSON.parse(runContent);
    expandedData = realRunData.expanded!;
  });

  describe('FAQ Generation - TDD Approach', () => {
    it('should generate FAQ section with proper heading', async () => {
      // Precondition: Real data has 9 faqBlocks
      expect(expandedData.faqBlocks).toHaveLength(9);

      // Test: Generate FAQ markdown section
      const faqMarkdown = PublisherAgent.generateFAQSection(expandedData.faqBlocks);

      // Postcondition: Output contains proper FAQ section
      expect(faqMarkdown).toContain('## Frequently Asked Questions');
      expect(faqMarkdown).toContain('**Do I need a special truck to tow a 5th wheel?**');
      expect(faqMarkdown).toContain('You need a pickup with sufficient payload');
    });

    it('should format all 9 FAQ items correctly', async () => {
      // Precondition: Verify we have exactly 9 FAQs
      const faqCount = expandedData.faqBlocks.length;
      expect(faqCount).toBe(9);

      // Test: Generate FAQ section
      const faqMarkdown = PublisherAgent.generateFAQSection(expandedData.faqBlocks);

      // Postcondition: All questions formatted as bold markdown
      const boldQuestions = faqMarkdown.match(/\*\*[^*]+\?\*\*/g);
      expect(boldQuestions).toHaveLength(9);

      // Postcondition: Each question followed by answer
      expect(faqMarkdown).toContain('**Do I need a special license to tow a 5th wheel?**');
      expect(faqMarkdown).toContain('Most U.S. states do not require');
      
      expect(faqMarkdown).toContain('**How much does a beginner-friendly 5th wheel cost in 2025?**');
      expect(faqMarkdown).toContain('Entry-level new models often start around');
    });

    it('should handle FAQ questions with proper spacing and formatting', async () => {
      // Test: Generate FAQ section
      const faqMarkdown = PublisherAgent.generateFAQSection(expandedData.faqBlocks);

      // Postcondition: Proper markdown spacing (double newlines between items)
      const sections = faqMarkdown.split('\n\n');
      expect(sections.length).toBeGreaterThan(9); // FAQ header + 9 Q&A pairs

      // Postcondition: No empty questions or answers
      expect(faqMarkdown).not.toContain('****'); // No empty bold text
      expect(faqMarkdown).not.toContain('**\n\n'); // No questions without answers
    });

    it('should integrate FAQ section into full markdown generation', async () => {
      // Precondition: Create mock final data for testing
      const mockFinal = {
        frontmatter: expandedData.frontmatter,
        content: expandedData.content,
        seoOptimizations: { titleOptimized: true, ctaIncluded: true },
        qualityMetrics: { readabilityGrade: 9 }
      };

      // Test: Generate complete markdown with FAQ integration
      const fullMarkdown = PublisherAgent.generateEnhancedMarkdown(mockFinal, expandedData);

      // Postcondition: Contains main content AND FAQ section
      expect(fullMarkdown).toContain('# Best 5th Wheel Trailers for Beginners');
      expect(fullMarkdown).toContain('## Frequently Asked Questions');
      expect(fullMarkdown).toContain('**Do I need a special truck to tow a 5th wheel?**');
      
      // Postcondition: FAQ section comes after main content
      const contentIndex = fullMarkdown.indexOf('# Best 5th Wheel Trailers');
      const faqIndex = fullMarkdown.indexOf('## Frequently Asked Questions');
      expect(faqIndex).toBeGreaterThan(contentIndex);
    });

    it('should handle missing or empty FAQ blocks gracefully', async () => {
      // Test: Empty FAQ blocks
      const emptyFaqMarkdown = PublisherAgent.generateFAQSection([]);
      
      // Postcondition: Returns empty string or minimal structure
      expect(emptyFaqMarkdown).toBe('');

      // Test: Undefined FAQ blocks
      const undefinedFaqMarkdown = PublisherAgent.generateFAQSection(undefined);
      
      // Postcondition: Handles gracefully
      expect(undefinedFaqMarkdown).toBe('');
    });
  });
});

   279â†’    "content": "# RV Battery Died â€” What Now? Immediate Fixes & Long-Term Solutions\n\nIntroduction\n\nA dead RV battery is stressful but fixable with safe immediate steps, simple diagnostics, and planned replacements. This guide covers emergency power options, basic testing, repair vs. replacement decisions, maintenance to prevent repeat failures, and when to call prosâ€”aimed at weekenders and full-time RVers who need practical, short-term and long-term guidance.\n\n## Immediate actions â€” stay safe and get power now\n\nDirect answer: Stop, isolate, and use safe emergency power options: disconnect shore power and inverter, wear PPE around batteries, confirm the battery is the issue with lights or a voltmeter, then attempt a jump-start, portable jump starter, or portable power station for essentials like lights and phone charging.[1][2][3][4][5]\n\nBefore touching anything, disconnect shore power and turn off the inverter/converter to avoid back-feed and sparks.[1] If you have flooded batteries, ensure good ventilation and eye protection; battery acid and hydrogen gas are hazards.[2] Avoid metal tools bridging terminals and always disconnect the negative terminal first when removing cables.[2]\n\nConfirm the battery is the problem by checking basic signs: interior lights, gauge readings, and shore power indicator lights; use a multimeter to read voltage (see diagnosis section).[6] If you need immediate power for essentials, use a rated portable jump starter or a donor vehicle matched to battery capacityâ€”follow safe connection order and start the donor first.[3]\n\nIf a jump-start isnâ€™t available or fails, a portable power station will run phone charging, LED lights and small electronics safely for hours; a generator restores full-power systems but use it outdoors and follow fuel/safety rules.[4][5] If stranded and unable to restore power, call roadside service or plan safe towing.\n\n### Safety checklist before touching batteries\n\nDirect answer: Always remove shore power, turn off charging equipment, wear gloves and eye protection, ventilate flooded batteries, and disconnect negative terminal first to minimize short and acid-exposure risks.[1][2]\n\nDisconnecting shore power and inverter prevents live circuits when you work on batteries and avoids unexpected energizing of systems.[1] Personal protective equipmentâ€”safety glasses and acid-resistant glovesâ€”is required for flooded cells due to possible electrolyte contact and hydrogen gas release.[2] Use insulated tools and never bridge terminals; remove the negative cable first and reconnect it last to lower short risk.[2]\n\n### How to jump-start an RV battery (step-by-step)\n\nDirect answer: Use a matched-capacity donor or a heavy-duty portable starter, attach positive-to-positive then negative-to-chassis ground on donor vehicle, start donor then RV, run the engine/charger to recharge, and monitor voltage and behavior after starting.[3]\n\nSelect a jumper rated for the battery type and capacityâ€”many RV house batteries are large deep-cycle units, so light-duty car jumpers may be inadequate.[3] Connect red to red (positive), then black to black (negative) on donor; if using a vehicle, attach the final negative clamp to a solid chassis ground on the RV, not the battery post, to reduce spark risk.[3] Start the donor, wait a few minutes, try starting the RV systems, then run the engine or a charger to bring the battery voltage up and observe for irregular charging or swelling.[3]\n\n### If the jump-start fails: emergency options\n\nDirect answer: Use a portable power station for lights and small devices, start a generator for full-power needs, or call professional roadside assistance or towing if you cannot safely restore power.[4][20]\n\nPortable power stations provide clean DC/AC power for LED lighting, phones, and small fridges for hours depending on capacity; they are safe and easy to use with no spark risk.[4] Portable generators restore larger loads but require ventilation and fuel; keep them outside and follow manufacturer instructions.[4] If electrical problems persist or the battery shows physical damage, seek professional roadside or RV club help for safe recovery.[20]\n\n## Diagnose the cause â€” test the battery and charging system\n\nDirect answer: Test battery voltage and state-of-charge with a multimeter, perform a load test or specific gravity check for flooded cells, and inspect the converter/alternator/solar controller and wiring for charging faults or parasitic drains.[6][7][8][9]\n\nStart with an open-circuit voltage reading: ~12.6V indicates full, ~12.0V is roughly 50% SOC, and below ~11.8â€“12.0V suggests deep discharge or failure.[6] After charging, measure voltage under load and after restâ€”poor recovery indicates sulfation or capacity loss and may require a load test or shop evaluation.[7]\n\nCheck charging sources: on shore power, confirm the converter/charger is supplying proper charge; on the road, verify the alternator or DC-to-DC charger is delivering current; for solar, inspect panels, wiring and the MPPT controller for faults or shading issues.[8] Look for parasitic drains such as lights, alarms, or faulty devices that draw current when systems are off.[9]\n\n### Testing with a multimeter â€” what the numbers mean\n\nDirect answer: Use a multimeter to read open-circuit voltage: ~12.6V = full, ~12.0V = ~50% SOC, <11.8â€“12.0V often indicates deep discharge; follow with a load test or specific gravity check on flooded batteries to confirm health.[6][7]\n\nMeasure voltage with the battery isolated and at rest for an accurate open-circuit reading.[6] A battery that wonâ€™t hold voltage under load or doesnâ€™t rise after charging likely has sulfation or cell failure and should be load-tested or brought to a shop for bench testing.[7]\n\n### Common charging system issues to check\n\nDirect answer: Inspect fuses and breakers for converter failures, check alternator outputs and isolator/charger wiring for poor alternator charging, and verify solar controller operation, panel orientation and connections if solar charging is used.[8]\n\nConverters can fail or trip breakersâ€”check for blown fuses or a failed charger if shore power is present but batteries donâ€™t charge.[8] On the road, low RPM alternator charging or a bad isolator/DC-to-DC unit can prevent proper charging; poor wiring or corroded terminals reduce charging current.[8] Solar issues often stem from shading, loose wiring, or a faulty charge controller setting for battery chemistry.[8]\n\n## Repair, replace, and short-term solutions\n\nDirect answer: Decide between reconditioning and replacement by age and capacity lossâ€”sulfated or ancient batteries usually need replacement; choose battery chemistry (flooded, AGM, GEL, LiFePO4) based on usage, weight, and charging compatibility; use portable stations or generators as short-term fixes.[10][11][12][4]\n\nReconditioning can help sulfated flooded batteries in some cases but is less likely to fully restore batteries with significant age or plate loss; use rules of thumb and professional tests to decide.[10] Battery chemistry tradeoffs include cost, weight and cycle lifeâ€”flooded is cheapest, AGM mid-range, lithium offers longest life and weight savings but costs more and may need charger/profile updates.[11]\n\nMatch the replacement batteryâ€™s Ah and group size to your RVâ€™s needsâ€”starting (CCA) batteries differ from deep-cycle house batteries; confirm terminal layout and physical fit before buying.[12]\n\n### Choosing the right battery for your RV use\n\nDirect answer: Weekenders who use shore power may prefer AGM or flooded batteries for cost; full-time RVers benefit from LiFePO4 for longer cycle life and faster rechargeâ€”consider weight, lifecycle and whether your charger supports the chemistry.[11][17]\n\nLithium batteries offer higher usable capacity and longer cycle life but require compatible charging systems or DC-to-DC chargers; AGM and flooded batteries are more forgiving with older converters but are heavier and have shorter lifespans.[11][17]\n\n### Cost & lifespan expectations\n\nDirect answer: Replacement costs roughly: flooded $100â€“$250, AGM $200â€“$500, lithium LiFePO4 $800+; typical lifespans: flooded 3â€“5 years, AGM 3â€“7 years, lithium 8â€“15+ years depending on cycles and care.[13][14]\n\nBudget for installation and proper recycling of old batteries; extended warranties and professional installation add cost but can protect the investment.[13][14]\n\n## Preventive maintenance & charging strategies to avoid future failures\n\nDirect answer: Regular maintenanceâ€”check water levels in flooded cells, clean terminals, tighten connectionsâ€”plus proper charging (avoid deep discharges, perform equalization for flooded batteries) and add battery monitors, DC-to-DC chargers, and MPPT solar for redundancy.[15][16][17]\n\nKeep batteries at a healthy state-of-charge during storage (50â€“80% for long-term storage depending on chemistry) and use a float or trickle charger to prevent self-discharge and sulfation.[16] Temperature affects capacityâ€”cold reduces usable capacity and hot accelerates degradation, so winterize appropriately.[16]\n\n### Setting up a robust charging system\n\nDirect answer: Combine shore power charging, alternator/DC-to-DC charging, and solar with MPPT for redundancy; use smart multi-stage chargers programmed for your battery chemistry and install a battery monitor/alarm to spot early issues.[18][17]\n\nA layered charging approach reduces single-point failures and keeps batteries topped off more consistently, extending life and preventing deep discharges.[18] Battery monitors report state-of-charge, voltage, and amp-hours usedâ€”early detection of drains or charger failures avoids surprises.[17]\n\n## When to call a pro, roadside help & insurance considerations\n\nDirect answer: Call a technician for repeated failures, inconsistent charging, swollen or leaking batteries, or if you lack tools/experience; roadside assistance and RV clubs offer jump-starts and towing, and keep records for warranties and insurance claims.[19][20][21]\n\nSwollen cases, electrolyte leaks, or repeated rapid failure are signs of serious battery or charging-system faultsâ€”stop using the battery and get professional help to avoid fire or corrosion damage.[19] RV clubs and many insurers include roadside help for jump-starts and towingâ€”check your plan before travel.[20]\n\n### Documenting failures for warranty or insurance claims\n\nDirect answer: Keep date-stamped photos, maintenance logs, and receipts; record service reports and error codes to support manufacturer warranty or extended warranty claims and to help insurance evaluations.[21]\n\nManufacturers and retailers have different warranty timelines and requirementsâ€”proof of maintenance and usage often affects coverage, so keep clear records and service invoices.[21]\n\n## Buying checklist & further resources\n\nDirect answer: Before buying, confirm group/size, Ah rating, terminal layout, weight and chemistry compatibility with your charger/inverter; buy from OEM dealers, specialty RV shops or reputable online retailers depending on warranty and support needs.[12][11]\n\nA pre-purchase checklist should include physical fit, rated Ah/C20, cold-cranking amps if used for starting, and whether you need a BMS or DC-to-DC charger for lithium conversions.[12][11] For next steps, read about battery monitoring, solar installation basics, and RV electrical safety to build a resilient system.\n",

   384â†’    "content": "# RV Battery Died â€” What Now? Immediate Fixes & Long-Term Solutions\n\nIntroduction\n\nA dead RV battery can ruin a trip, strand you at a campground, or create safety hazards if not handled properly. This expanded guide walks through immediate emergency steps, safe jump-start procedures, how to diagnose whether the battery or the charging system failed, repair vs. replacement decisions with specific model examples and costs, and robust preventive strategies (charging system architecture, monitoring, maintenance and seasonal care). The target reader is any RVerâ€”from weekends-only families to full-time vanlifersâ€”who wants practical, step-by-step actions and clear decision frameworks.\n\n## Immediate actions â€” stay safe and get power now\n\nDirect answer: Stop, isolate, and use safe emergency power options. Disconnect shore power and inverter/converter, put on PPE around batteries, verify the battery is the issue using lights or a voltmeter, then try a jump-start (heavy-duty jumper or donor vehicle), a portable jump starter, or a portable power station to run essentials like LED lights and phones. If those fail, use a generator (outside) or call roadside service.[1][2][3][4][5]\n\nWhy the order matters: leaving shore power or an inverter connected while you work on batteries risks creating a back-feed. A back-fed inverter can present live AC on DC components or energize systems unexpectedly.[1]\n\n**Image Placeholder**: [after-h2-1] A photograph showing a typical RV battery compartment with clearly labeled positive and negative terminals and PPE (gloves and safety glasses) on a workbench. Alt: \"RV battery compartment with labeled terminals and protective gloves and goggles nearby\".\n\n### Quick safety checklist â€” first 5 things to do\n\n- [ ] Turn off shore power at the pedestal and disconnect shore cord from the RV.\n- [ ] Turn off the inverter and converter/charger and all loads in the RV.\n- [ ] Put on safety glasses and acid-resistant gloves if batteries are flooded.\n- [ ] Check for visible damage: bulging cases, cracking, leaks, or strong sulfur smell â€” if present, do not attempt to jump; call a pro.[19]\n- [ ] Use insulated tools and never lay a wrench across both terminals; disconnect negative terminal first if you must remove cables.[2]\n\nSafety details: Flooded lead-acid batteries emit hydrogen gas during chargingâ€”this is explosive in confined areas. Always ventilate battery compartments (open vents, run fans) and avoid sparks.[2][22]\n\n## Confirming the problem â€” how to tell if the battery is dead\n\nDirect answer: Use simple tests first: turn on interior lights, check 12V gauge, and use a digital multimeter for an open-circuit voltage reading. Then perform a load test, check specific gravity on flooded cells, and inspect charging sources (shore power charger, alternator/DC-to-DC charger, solar controller).[6][7][8][9]\n\nOpen-circuit voltage quick reference (battery at rest, no loads for >4 hours):\n\n- 12.6â€“12.8 V = Full (100% SOC)\n- 12.3â€“12.4 V = ~75% SOC\n- 12.0 V = ~50% SOC\n- 11.8â€“11.9 V = deep discharge (potential damage)\n- <11.8 V = likely sulfation or internal failure[6][7]\n\n**Image Placeholder**: [in-section-diagnose] Close-up of a hand-held multimeter reading 12.0V across battery terminals. Alt: \"multimeter measuring RV battery voltage at terminals\".\n\nPractical verification steps:\n\n1. With the RV idle and no charging connected, measure battery voltage with a digital multimeter across positive and negative terminals.[6]\n2. Turn on a 12V load (like headlights) and watch voltage drop. A healthy battery holds voltage; a failing battery collapses rapidly under a moderate load â€” that indicates low capacity.[7]\n3. For flooded cells, measure specific gravity with a hydrometer; variance between cells >0.05 indicates cell issues.[7]\n\nIf voltage reads normal but the RV wonâ€™t start or power devices, check fuses, battery isolator switches, and voltage drop across cables (poor connections increase resistance and reduce usable current).[8]\n\n## How to jump-start an RV battery (step-by-step)\n\nDirect answer: Use a matched-capacity donor vehicle or a heavy-duty portable starter. Attach positive-to-positive, then negative-to-chassis ground on the donor vehicle (or to RV chassis). Start the donor, then start the RV. Run the donor engine to charge and monitor voltage. Remove clamps in reverse order and recharge battery fully with a proper charger.\n\nWhen to use a portable starter: a high-capacity portable jump starter (12V, rated for >1000A peak for house battery banks or dedicated starters) is safer than relying on a small passenger car when the RV has large deep-cycle batteries.[3]\n\nStep-by-step (expanded):\n\n1. Park donor vehicle close but not touching the RV. Set both vehicles to park/neutral and engage parking brakes.\n2. Turn off shore power, inverter, converter, and all RV loads.[1]\n3. Inspect batteries visually. If case is cracked, leaking, swollen, or venting heavily â€” do not jump-start; call a technician.[19]\n4. Connect clamps in this order: donor positive to donor positive, donor negative to donor chassis ground (away from battery), RV positive to RV battery positive, RV negative to RV chassis ground (or if jump-starting a starter battery, to engine block). The last connection should be ground to reduce spark risk near the battery.[3]\n5. Start the donor vehicle. Let it idle 2â€“5 minutes to supply current.\n6. If using a portable starter, power it on and follow its sequence. Start the RV systems and charge bank slowly.\n7. Once systems are up, run the donor engine for 10â€“30 minutes or connect a proper multi-stage charger to restore charge. Monitor battery temperature and voltage.[3]\n8. Remove clamps in reverse order: last removed positive, then negative. Reconnect battery negative last if you removed it earlier.[3]\n\nCommon mistakes to avoid:\n\n- Attaching clamps in the wrong order (can create sparks near battery).\n- Connecting negative to battery post (risk of sparks); use chassis ground instead.[3]\n- Using a small automotive jumper on a large deep-cycle house bank â€” it may not deliver enough current and can overheat cables.\n\n## If the jump-start fails: emergency power options and safe next steps\n\nDirect answer: Use a portable power station for lights and small electronics, run a generator outside with proper ventilation for larger loads, or call roadside assistance or a professional RV electrician if the battery is physically damaged or the vehicle won't accept a charge.[4][20]\n\nPortable power station uses and sizing:\n\n- 300â€“500 Wh: phone/laptop charging and a few LED lights for several hours.\n- 1000 Wh+: can run a 12V fridge for several hours but depends on fridge efficiency.\n\nGenerators: choose a quiet inverter generator sized for your loads (e.g., 2000â€“3000W for AC charging and small HVAC). Always operate generators outdoors 10â€“20 feet from openings to prevent CO buildup.[4]\n\nEmergency checklist:\n\n- [ ] Switch off non-essential loads to conserve remaining power.\n- [ ] Use portable power station for lights, comms, and critical medical equipment if needed.\n- [ ] Start generator outdoors only; run carbon monoxide detector while operating.[4]\n- [ ] If battery smells strongly of rotten eggs, is leaking, or has a bulge, stop and call a proâ€”these are fire/explosion risks.[19]\n\n## Diagnose the cause â€” test the battery and charging system thoroughly\n\nDirect answer: Test battery voltage and state-of-charge with a multimeter, perform a load test or specific gravity check for flooded batteries, inspect converter/charger, alternator/DC-to-DC charger, solar controller, and wiring for charging faults or parasitic drains. Use a battery monitor to collect amp-hour data over several days for accurate diagnosis.[6][7][8][9][17]\n\nTesting steps (practical):\n\n1. Measure open-circuit voltage after 4+ hours rest. Record reading.[6]\n2. Apply a known resistive load (headlights or dedicated load tester) and record voltage under load; collapse indicates poor capacity.[7]\n3. Charge fully with a multi-stage charger and monitor recovery voltage and specific gravity per cell for flooded batteries. Cells that show lower gravity after equalization may be bad.[7]\n4. Check the converter/charger on shore power: measure the DC charging voltage and current. Typical bulk charging will be 14.2â€“14.6V for flooded/AGM or per manufacturer for lithium (often 14.2â€“14.6V for lead-acid, 14.4V for AGM; lithium needs a different profileâ€”see manufacturer specs).[8][17]\n5. On the road, confirm alternator output and voltage at battery with engine at ~2000 RPM; low wire gauge or poor connections may reduce charging current.[8]\n6. Inspect solar panels and MPPT controller: check array open-circuit voltage and controller readouts; shading or loose connectors can dramatically reduce output.[8]\n7. Monitor for parasitic draws using a clamp meter or amp-hour meter; place meter between battery negative and negative bus and watch for current draw when everything should be off.[9]\n\n**Image Placeholder**: [in-section-diagnose-2] An RV electrical bay with labeled converter, DC-to-DC charger, and battery monitor display. Alt: \"RV electrical bay showing converter, DC-to-DC charger, and battery monitor\".\n\n### Common charging system faults and how to check them\n\n| Fault | Symptom | Quick check |\n|------|---------|-------------|\n| Blown converter fuse or failed charger | Shore power but no charge to battery | Check AC breaker, converter lights, and DC output with meter[8]\n| Bad alternator/isolator | Battery not charging on road | Measure voltage at battery with engine running (should be >13.5V)[8]\n| Corroded terminals or undersized cables | Low charging current despite functioning charger | Inspect cable size (use 2/0â€“4 AWG for large banks), clean terminals[8]\n| Solar panel shading/MPPT error | Low or zero solar current in sun | Check panel voltage, MPPT error codes; inspect connectors[8]\n| Parasitic drain | Battery drains overnight | Use clamp meter or amp-hour meter to find source, inspect aftermarket devices[9]\n\n## Repair, reconditioning, or replacement â€” how to decide\n\nDirect answer: Evaluate age, capacity loss (via amp-hour tests or load tests), and physical condition. Batteries older than recommended service life with consistent capacity loss should be replaced. Reconditioning may help recently sulfated flooded batteries, but it rarely fully restores heavily aged or physically degraded batteries.[10][11][12]\n\nDecision framework:\n\n- Age < 3 years and low capacity: consider reconditioning and detailed testing (bench load test).\n- Age 3â€“5 years and reduced capacity: likely replacement, consider stepping up chemistry if needs changed.\n- Visible damage/leaks/swelling: immediate replacement.[10][19]\n\nComparison table â€” battery chemistries for RV house banks\n\n| Chemistry | Typical Use Case | Pros | Cons | Typical Cost (12V 100Ah equiv.) | Typical Lifespan (cycles) |\n|----------|------------------|------|------|-------------------------------:|--------------------------:|\n| Flooded lead-acid (wet) | Budget users, stationary | Lowest upfront cost, simple charging | Heavy, maintenance (water), venting | $120â€“$250 | 300â€“800 cycles (3â€“5 years)\n| AGM (absorbent glass mat) | Mid-range, weekenders | Sealed (no watering), better cycle life than flooded | Heavier than lithium, pricier | $200â€“$500 | 500â€“1000 cycles (3â€“7 years)\n| GEL | Off-grid with slow charge | Good deep discharge tolerance | Sensitive to charging voltage, less common | $300â€“$600 | 500â€“1000 cycles\n| LiFePO4 (lithium) | Full-timers, boondockers | High usable capacity, lighter, long life | Higher upfront cost, needs compatible charging | $800â€“$1600+ | 2000â€“5000 cycles (8â€“15+ years)[11][13][14]\n\nSample battery specs (common models)\n\n| Model | Chemistry | Nominal Voltage | Ah (usable) | Weight | Typical MSRP |\n|-------|----------:|---------------:|-----------:|------:|-------------:|\n| Trojan T-105 (GC2 pair) | Flooded | 6V (wired 12V) | 225 Ah (C20) | ~125 lb (pair) | $200â€“$400 per battery (pair cost varies)[13]\n| Renogy 12V 100Ah Deep Cycle AGM | AGM | 12V | 100 Ah | ~62 lb | $220â€“$350[14]\n| Battle Born 12V 100Ah LiFePO4 | LiFePO4 | 12.8V | 100 Ah (usable ~100%) | ~31 lb | $899â€“$1200[11]\n\nNote on capacity: LiFePO4 usable capacity is typically ~90â€“100% of rated Ah vs. lead-acid usable ~50% without damaging cycle life; this is why LiFePO4 can often be sized smaller for the same usable energy.[11]\n\n### Cost & lifespan expectations (expanded)\n\nReplacement cost ranges (setup dependent):\n\n- Single flooded 6V GC2 pair for a house bank: $250â€“$600 installed.\n- AGM 12V 100Ah: $200â€“$500 each; many systems use 2+ batteries.\n- LiFePO4 100Ah 12.8V: $800â€“$1,600 each depending on brand, BMS, and warranty.[13][14]\n\nInstallation, waste disposal, and possible upgrades (DC-to-DC charger, new BMS) add to total cost. Example: upgrading to a lithium bank and installing a DC-to-DC charger and new inverter-friendly settings can add $1,500â€“$3,500 to battery cost depending on labor and parts.[11]\n\n## Practical real-world examples (case studies)\n\nCase study 1 â€” The Johnson family (weekend campers)\n\nMeet the Johnsons: a family of four who camp two weekends a month and use shore power most of the time.
